metadata.title: The SARS-CoV-2 conserved macrodomain is a highly efficient ADP-ribosylhydrolase 1 enzyme 2 3

Molecular Graphics and Modeling Laboratory and the Computational Chemical Biology Core

body_text.text: pathogenesis in multiple animal models of CoV infection, implicating this domain as a 26 prominent virulence factor and potential therapeutic target. Mac1 likely counters host-mediated 27 antiviral ADP-ribosylation, a posttranslational modification that is part of the host response to 28 viral infections. Here we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 in complex with 29 ADP-ribose refined at 2.2 Å resolution. SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV Mac1 30 exhibit similar structural folds and ADP-ribose binding modes as shown by structural 31 comparison. All three CoV Mac1 proteins bound to ADP-ribose with low μ M affinities. They 32 also demonstrated highly efficient de-MARylating activity, which was greater than that of the 33 human Mdo2 macrodomain. We conclude that the SARS-CoV-2 and other CoV Mac1 proteins 34 are highly efficient ADP-ribosylhydrolases with strikingly similar activity, indicating that 35 compounds targeting CoV Mac1 proteins may have broad antiviral activity against CoVs. 36 37 IMPORTANCE 38 SARS-CoV-2 has recently emerged into the human population and has led to a worldwide 39 pandemic of COVID-19 that has caused nearly 300K deaths worldwide. With, no currently 40 approved treatments, novel therapeutic strategies are desperately needed. All coronaviruses 41 encode for a highly conserved macrodomain (Mac1) that binds to and removes ADP-ribose, a 42 post-translation modification, from proteins. This protein domain is essential for CoV 43 pathogenesis and may be a novel therapeutic target. Thus, understanding its biochemistry and 44 enzyme activity are critical first steps for these efforts. Here we report the crystal structure of 45 SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 in complex with ADP-ribose, and describe its ADP-ribose binding and 46 hydrolysis activities in direct comparison to SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV Mac1 proteins, and a 47 human macrodomain. These results are an important first step for the design and testing of 48 potential therapies targeting this unique protein domain. 49

The recently emerged pandemic outbreak of COVID-19 is caused by a novel coronavirus 51 named severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) 1,2 . As of May 11, 2020 52 this virus is responsible for ~ 4 million cases of COVID-19 and >285,000 deaths worldwide. 53 SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the lineage B β -CoVs with overall high sequence similarity with 54 other SARS-like CoVs, including SARS-CoV. While most of the genome is >80% similar with 55 SARS-CoV, there are regions where amino acid conservation is significantly lower. As expected, 56 the most divergent proteins in the SARS-CoV-2 genome from SARS-CoV include the Spike 57 glycoprotein and several accessory proteins including 8a (absent), 8b (extended), and 3b 58 (truncated). However, somewhat unexpectedly, several non-structural proteins also show 59 significant divergence from SARS-CoV, including non-structural proteins 3, 4, and 7, which 60 could affect the biology of SARS-CoV-2 3,4 . 61

Coronaviruses encode 16 non-structural proteins that are translated from two open 62 reading frames (ORFs), replicase 1a and 1ab (rep1a and rep1ab) 5 . The largest non-structural 63 protein is non-structural protein 3 (nsp3) that encodes for multiple modular protein domains. 64

These domains in SARS-CoV-2 diverge in amino acid sequence from SARS-CoV as much as 65 30%, and it includes a large insertion of 25-41 residues just upstream of the first of three tandem 66 macrodomains (Mac1, Mac2, and Mac3) (Fig. 1A) 3 . In addition to this insertion, the individual 67 macrodomains show large amounts of amino acid divergence. Mac1 diverges 28% from CoV and 59% from MERS-CoV, while Mac2 and Mac3 diverge 24% from SARS-CoV. It is 69 feasible that these significant sequence differences could impact the unique biology of SARS-70

CoV-2. However, macrodomains have a highly conserved structure, and thus sequence 71 divergence may have little impact on their overall function. Mac1 is present in all CoVs, unlike 72 Mac2 and Mac3, and early structural and biochemical data demonstrated that it contains a 73 conserved three-layered α /β/α fold and binds to ADP-ribose, poly-ADP-ribose, and other related 74 molecules [6] [7] [8] [9] [10] . ADP-ribose is buried in a hydrophobic cleft where the ADP-ribose binds to 75 several highly-conserved residues such as aspartic acid at position 23 (D23) and asparagine at 76 position 41 (N41) of SARS-CoV 6 . Mac1 homologs are also found in alphaviruses, Hepatitis E 77 virus, and Rubella virus, and structural analysis of these macrodomains have demonstrated that 78 they are very similar to CoV Mac1 11,12 and are all members of the larger MacroD-type 79 macrodomain family, which includes human macrodomains Mdo1 and Mdo2 13 . 80

The CoV Mac1 was originally called an ADP-ribose-1"-phosphatase (ADRP) based on 81 data demonstrating that it could remove the phosphate group from ADP-ribose-1"-phosphate 6-8 . 82 However, the activity was rather modest, and it was unclear why this would impact a virus 83 infection. More recently it has been demonstrated that CoV Mac1 can hydrolyze the bond 84 between amino acid chains and ADP-ribose molecules 14-16 , indicating that it can reverse protein 85 ADP-ribosylation 6,8 . ADP-ribosylation is a post-translational modification catalyzed by ADP-86 ribosyltransferases (also known as PARPs) through transferring an ADP-ribose moiety from 87 NAD + onto target proteins 17 . The ADP-ribose is transferred as single mono-ADP-ribose unit 88 (MAR), or single units of ADP-ribose are transferred consecutively to form a poly-ADP-ribose 89 chain (PAR). CoV Mac1 efficiently hydrolyzes MAR, but has minimal activity against PAR 14,15 . 90 Several MARylating PARPs are induced by interferon (IFN) and are known to inhibit virus 91 replication, implicating ADP-ribosylation in the host-response to infection 18 . 92

Several reports have addressed the role of Mac1 on the replication and pathogenesis of 93 CoVs, mostly using the mutation of a highly conserved asparagine to alanine. This mutation 94 abolished the ADP-ribosylhydrolase activity of SARS-CoV Mac1 16 . This mutation has minimal 95 effects on virus replication in transformed cells, but reduces viral load, leads to enhanced IFN 96 production, and strongly attenuates both Murine Hepatitis Virus (MHV) and SARS-CoV in 97 mouse models of infection 7, 16, 19, 20 . MHV Mac1 was also required for efficient replication in 98 primary macrophages, which could be partially rescued by PARP inhibitors or siRNA 99 knockdown of PARP12 or PARP14 21 . These data suggest that Mac1's likely function is to 100 counter PARP-mediated anti-viral ADP-ribosylation 22 . Mutations in the alphavirus and HEV 101 macrodomain are also known to have substantial phenotypic effects on virus replication and 102 pathogenesis 14,23-26 . As viral macrodomains are clearly important virulence factors, they are 103 considered to be potential targets for anti-viral therapeutics 22 . 104
Based on the close structural and functional similarities between viral macrodomains we 105 hypothesized that SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 has similar binding and hydrolysis activity as other CoV 106

Mac1 enzymes. In this study, we determined the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 107 protein bound to ADP-ribose. Binding to ADP-ribose was further confirmed and directly 108 compared to a human macrodomain (Mdo2) and the SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV Mac1 proteins 109 by several in vitro assays. Finally, using an auto-modified protein substrate, we demonstrated 110 that SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV, and MERS-CoV Mac1 proteins are very efficient ADP-111 ribosylhydrolases. These results will be instrumental in the design and testing of novel 112 therapeutic agents targeting the CoV Mac1 protein domain. 113

Structure of the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 complexed with ADP-ribose. To create recombinant 115 SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 for structure determination and enzyme assays, nucleotides 3348-3872 of 116 SARS-CoV-2 isolate Wuhan-hu-1, representing amino acids I1023-K1197 of rep1a, were cloned 117 into a bacterial expression vector containing an N-terminal His tag and TEV cleavage site. We 118 obtained large amounts (>100 mg) of highly purified recombinant protein (Fig. S1A) . A small 119 amount of this protein was digested by the TEV protease to obtain protein devoid of any extra 120 tags for crystallization and used to obtain crystals from which the structure was determined ( The structure of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 complexed with ADP-ribose was obtained using X-126 ray diffraction data to 2.2 Å resolution and contained four molecules in the asymmetric unit that 127 were nearly identical. The polypeptide chains could be traced from V3-M171 for subunits A/C 128 and V3-K172 for subunits B/D. Superposition of subunits B-D onto subunit A (169 residues 129 aligned) yielded RMSD deviations of 0.17 Å, 0.17 Å and 0.18 Å respectively between Cα atoms. 130

As such, subunit A was used for the majority of the structure analysis described herein. The 131 SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 protein adopted a fold consistent with the MacroD subfamily of 132 macrodomains that contains a core composed of a mixed arrangement of 7 β -sheets (parallel and 133 antiparallel) that are flanked by 6 α -helices ( Fig. 2A-B) . 134

As mentioned above, apo crystals were never observed for our construct, though the apo 135 structure has been solved by researchers at The Center for Structural Genomics of Infectious 136 Diseases (PDB 6WEN) 28 and University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (PDB 6WEY) 27 . Further 137 analysis of the amino acid sequences used for expression and purification revealed that our 138 construct had 5 additional residues at the C-terminus (MKSEK) and differs slightly at the N-139 terminus as well (GIE vs GE) relative to 6WEN. In addition, the sequence used to obtain the 140 structure of 6WEY is slightly shorter than SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 at both the N and C-terminal 141 regions (Fig. S2A) . To assess the effect of these additional residues on crystallization, chain B 142 of the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1, which was traced to residue K172, was superimposed onto subunit A 143 of PDB 6W02 29 , a previously determined structure of ADP-ribose bound SARS-CoV-2 Mac1. 144

Analysis of the crystal packing of 6W02 indicates that the additional residues at the C-terminus 145 would clash with symmetry related molecules (Fig. S2B ). This suggests that the presence of 146 these extra residues at the C-terminus likely prevented the generation of the more tightly packed 147 crystal forms obtained for 6W02 and 6WEY, which diffracted to high resolution. 148

The ADP-ribose binding pocket contained large regions of positive electron density 149 consistent with ADP-ribose molecules (Fig. 3A) . The adenine forms two hydrogen bonds with 150 D22-I23, which makes up a small loop between β 2 and the N-terminal half of α 1. The side chain 151 of D22 interacts with N6, while the backbone nitrogen atom of I23 interacts with N1, in a very 152 similar fashion to the SARS-CoV macrodomain 6 . A large number of contacts are made in the 153 loop between β 3 and α 2 which includes many highly-conserved residues, including a GGG 154 (motif) and N40, which is completely conserved in all enzymatically active macrodomains 30 . 155 N40 is positioned to make hydrogen bonds with the 3' OH groups of the distal ribose, as well as 156 a conserved water molecule. K44 and G46 also make hydrogen bonds with the 2' OH of the 157 distal ribose, G48 makes contact with the 1' OH and a water that resides near the catalytic site, 158 while the backbone nitrogen atom of V49 hydrogen bonds with the α -phosphate. The other major 159 interactions with ADP-ribose occur in residues G130, I131, and F132 that are in the loop 160 between β 6 and α 5 (Fig. 3B ). The α -phosphate accepts a hydrogen bond from the nitrogen atom 161 of I131, while the β -phosphate accepts hydrogen bonds from the backbone nitrogen atom of 162 G130 and F132. Loops β 3-α2 and β 6-α5 are connected by an isoleucine bridge that forms a 163 narrow channel around the diphosphate which helps position the terminal ribose for water-164 mediated catalysis 6 . Additionally, a network of direct contacts of ADP-ribose to solvent along 165 with water mediated contacts to the protein are shown (Fig. 3C) . their affinity to ADP-ribose. All CoV Mac1 proteins bound to ADP-ribose with low micromolar 202 affinity (7-16 μ M), while human Mdo2 bound with an affinity about 10-times stronger (~220 203 nM) ( Fig. 5A-B) . As a control we tested the ability of the MERS-CoV macrodomain to bind to 204 ATP, and only observed minimal binding with mM affinity (data not shown). At higher 205 concentrations, the SARS-CoV-2 macrodomain caused a slightly endothermic reaction, 206 potentially the result of protein aggregation or a change in conformation (Fig. 5A ). The CoV Mac1 had a greater affinity for ADP-ribose than SARS-CoV or SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 in the 208 ITC assay (Fig. 5A-B) , however, our results found the differences between these macrodomain 209 proteins to be much closer than previously reported 9 . As an alternate method to confirm ADP-210 ribose binding, we conducted a thermal shift assay. All 4 macrodomains tested denatured at 211 higher temperatures with the addition of ADP-ribose (Fig. 5C ). We conclude that lineage B and 212 lineage C β -CoV Mac1 proteins bind to ADP-ribose with similar affinities. 213

the ADP-ribosylhydrolase activity of coronaviruses Mac1, we first tested the viability of using 215 antibodies to detect mono-ADP-ribosylated protein. Previously, only radiolabeled NAD + has 216 been used to label ADP-ribosylated protein 14,15 . To create a mono-ADP-ribosylated substrate, the 217 catalytic domain of the PARP10 (GST-PARP10 CD) protein was incubated with NAD + , leading 218 to its auto-ADP-ribosylation. We then tested a panel of monoclonal antibodies that detect mono-219 ADP-ribose (MAR), poly-ADP-ribose (PAR), or both MAR and PAR for the ability to detect 220 MARylated PARP10. The anti-MAR and anti-MAR/PAR antibodies, but not anti-PAR antibody, 221 bound to MARylated PARP10 (Fig. S4 ). From herein we utilized the anti-MAR antibody to 222 detect ADP-ribosylated PARP10. 223
body_text.section: CoV macrodomains are highly efficient mono-ADP-ribosylhydrolases. To examine 214

body_text.text: We next tested the ability of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 to remove ADP-ribose from 224 MARylated PARP10. SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 and MARylated PARP10 were incubated at 225 equimolar amounts of protein at 37 o C and the reaction was stopped at 5, 10, 20, 30, 45 or 60 226 minutes (Fig. 6A) . As a control, MARylated PARP10 was incubated alone for 60 minutes at 227 37 o C. Each reaction had equivalent amounts of MARylated PARP10 and Mac1 which was 228 confirmed by Coomassie Blue staining (Fig. 6A ). An immediate reduction of more than 50% 229 band intensity was observed within five minutes, and the ADP-ribose modification was nearly 230 completely removed by SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 within 30 minutes (Fig. 6A ). The MARylated 231 PAPR10 bands intensities were calculated, plotted, and fit to a non-linear regression curve (Fig.  232   6B ). This result indicates that the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 protein is a highly efficient ADP-233 ribosylhydrolase. 234

body_text.text: CoV, and MERS-CoV and human Mdo2. These proteins were incubated with MARylated 236 PARP10 as described above and the removal of MAR was analyzed at 5, 15 and 30 minutes ( Here we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1. It has a conserved three-250 layered α /β/α fold typical of the MacroD family of macrodomains, and is extremely similar to 251 other CoV Mac1 proteins (Fig. 2-4) . The conserved coronavirus macrodomain (Mac1) was 252 initially described as an ADP-ribose-1"-phosphatase (ADRP), as it was shown to be structurally 253 similar to yeast enzymes that have this enzymatic activity 31 . Early biochemical studies confirmed 254 this activity for CoV Mac1, though its phosphatase activity for this substrate was rather modest 6-255 8 . Later, it was shown that mammalian macrodomain proteins could remove ADP-ribose from 256 protein substrates, indicating protein de-ADP-ribosylation as a more likely function for the viral 257 macrodomains 30,32,33 . Shortly thereafter, the SARS-CoV, hCoV-229E, FIPV, several alphavirus, 258 and the hepatitis E virus macrodomains were demonstrated to have de-ADP-ribosylating activity 259 14-16 . However, this activity has not yet been reported for the MERS-CoV or SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 260 protein. In this study, we show that the Mac1 proteins from SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and SARS-261
body_text.section: CoV macrodomains are highly efficient mono-ADP-ribosylhydrolases. To examine 214

body_text.text: CoV-2 hydrolyze ADP-ribose from a protein substrate (Fig. 6) . Their activities were similar 262 despite sequence divergence of almost 60% between SARS-CoV-2 and MERS-CoV. We then 263 compared these activities to the human Mdo2 macrodomain. Mdo2 had a greater affinity for 264 ADP-ribose than the viral enzymes, but had significantly reduced enzyme activity in our 265 experiments. These results suggest that the human and viral enzymes have sufficient structural 266 differences that result in differences in biochemical activities. Finally, while all previous studies 267 of macrodomain de-ADP-ribosylation had used radiolabeled substrate, we obtained highly 268 repeatable and robust data utilizing antibodies designed to specifically recognized mono-ADP-269 ribose 34 . The use of these antibodies should enhance the feasibility of this assay for many labs 270 that are not equipped for radioactive work. 271
body_text.section: CoV macrodomains are highly efficient mono-ADP-ribosylhydrolases. To examine 214

body_text.text: The functional importance of Mac1 has been demonstrated in several reports, mostly 272 utilizing the mutation of a highly conserved asparagine that mediates contact with the distal 273 ribose (Fig. 3B) 16, 19, 20 CoV-2 Mac1 structure to identify the mechanisms it uses to bind to its biologically relevant 287 protein substrates, remove ADP-ribose from these proteins, and potentially define the precise 288 function for Mac1 in CoV replication and pathogenesis. These studies will be critical for the 289 design and development of highly-specific Mac1 inhibitors that could be used therapeutically to 290 mitigate COVID-19 or future CoV outbreaks. 291

body_text.text: Plasmids 293

The SARS-CoV macrodomain (Mac1) (residues 1000-1172 of pp1a) was cloned into the 294 pET21a+ expression vector with an N-terminal His tag. The MERS-CoV Mac1 (residues 1110-295 1273 of pp1a) was also cloned into pET21a+ with a C-terminal His tag. SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 296 (residues 1023-1197 of pp1a) was cloned into the pET30a+ expression vector with an N-terminal 297

His tag and a TEV cleavage site (Synbio). The pETM-CN Mdo2 Mac1 (residues 7-243) 298 expression vector with an N-terminal His-TEV-V5 tag and the pGEX4T-PARP10CD (residues 299 818-1025) expression vector with an N-terminal GST tag were previously described 30 (Ivan 300
Ahel, Oxford University). All plasmids were confirmed by restriction digest, PCR, and direct 301 sequencing. 302

A single colony of E. coli cells (C41(DE3)) containing plasmids harboring the constructs 304 of the macrodomain proteins was inoculated into 10mL LB media and grown overnight at 37°C 305 with shaking at 250 rpm. The overnight culture was transferred to a shaker flask containing 2X 306 1L TB media at 37 o C until the OD600 reached to about 0.7. The proteins were either induced 307 with 0.4 mM IPTG at 37C for 3 hours, or 17°C for 20 hours. Cells were pelleted at 3500 × g for 308 10 min and frozen at -80°C. Frozen cells were thawed at room temperature, resuspended in 309 50mM tris (pH 7.6), 150mM NaCl, and sonicated using the following cycle parameters: 310 Amplitude: 50%, Pulse length: 30 seconds, Number of pulses: 12, while incubating on ice for 311 >1min between pulses. The soluble fraction was obtained by centrifuging the cell lysate at 312 45,450 × g for 30 minutes at 4°C. The expressed soluble proteins were purified by affinity 313 chromatography using a 5 ml prepacked HisTrap HP column on an AKTA Pure protein 314 purification system (GE Healthcare). The fractions were further purified by size-exclusion 315 chromatography (SEC) with a Superdex 75 10/300 GL column equilibrated with 20mM Tris (pH 316 8.0), 150 mM NaCl and the protein sized as a monomer relative to the column calibration 317 standards. To cleave off the His tag from the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1, purified TEV protease was 318 added to purified SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 protein at a ratio of 1:10 (w/w), and then passed back 319 through the Ni-NTA HP column. Protein was collected in the flow through and equilibrated with 320

All statistical analyses were done using an unpaired two-tailed student's t-test to assess 401 differences in mean values between groups, and graphs are expressed as mean ±SD. 3) R factor = Σ hkl ||F obs (hkl) | -|F calc (hkl) || / Σ hkl |F obs (hkl)|; Rfree is calculated in an 546 identical manner using 5% of randomly selected reflections that were not included in the refinement. ADP-ribose is rendered as gray cylinders with oxygens and nitrogens colored red and blue, 560 respectively. 561 Figure 1 . The SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 is a small domain within nsp3 and is highly conserved between other human CoV Mac1 protein domains. (A) Cartoon Schematic of the SARS-CoV-2 non-structural protein 3. The conserved macrodomain, or Mac1, is highlighted in yellow. (B) Sequence alignment of Mac1 from the highly-pathogenic human CoVs. Sequences were aligned using the ClustalW method from Clustal Omega online tool with manual adjustment. Identical residues are bolded, shaded in grey, and marked with asterisks. Figure 2 . Structure of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 complexed with ADP-ribose. A) The structure was rendered as a blend through model from the N-terminus (blue) to the C-terminus (red). B) The structure was colored by secondary structure showing sheets (magenta) and helices (green). The ADP-ribose is rendered as gray cylinders with oxygens and nitrogens colored red and blue, respectively. The SARS-CoV-2 macrodomain (A) or multiple macrodomain proteins (C) were incubated with MARylated PARP10 CD in vitro for the indicated times at 37°C. ADP-ribosylated PARP10 CD was detected by immunoblot (IB) with anti-ADP-ribose antibody (Millipore-Sigma MAB1076). Total PARP10 CD and macrodomain protein levels were determined by Coomassie Blue (CB) staining. PARP10 CD incubated alone at 37°C was stopped at 0, 30 or 60 minutes. B,D) level of de-ADP-ribosylation was measured by quantifying band intensity using Image J software. Intensity values were plotted and fit to a non-linear regression curve (B) or as bar graphs representing the means with error bars representing standard deviation (D). Results in A and C are representative experiments of two and three independent experiments, respectively. Data in B and D represent the combined results of two and three independent experiments, respectively. Asterisks indicate statistical significance between these samples and the same timepoint from samples treated with Mdo2.

FIGREF1.text: 166 Comparison of SARS-CoV-2 with other CoV macrodomain structures. We next 167 sought to compare the SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 to other deposited structures of this protein. 168 Superposition with Apo (6WEN) and ADP-ribose complexed protein (6W02) yielded RMSD of 169 0.48 Å (168 residues) and 0.37 Å (165 residues), respectively, indicating a high degree of 170 similarity (Fig. S3A-B). Comparison of the ADP-ribose binding site of SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 with 171 that of the apo structure (6WEN) revealed minor conformational differences in order to 172 accommodate ADP-ribose binding. The loop between β 3 and α 2 (H45-V49) undergoes a change 173 in conformation and the sidechain of F132 is moved out of the ADP-ribose binding site (Fig. 174 S3C). Our ADP-ribose bound structure is nearly identical to 6W02, except for slight deviations 175 in the β 3-α2 loop and an altered conformation of F156, where the aryl ring of F156 is moved 176 closer to the adenine ring (Fig. S3 C-D). However, this is likely a result of crystal packing as 177 F156 adopts this conformation in each subunit and would likely clash with subunit residues 178 related by either crystallographic or non-crystallographic symmetry. 179 We next compared the ADP-ribose bound SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 structure with that of 180 SARS-CoV (PDB 2FAV) and MERS-CoV (PDB 5HOL) Mac1 proteins. Superposition yielded 181 RMSD deviations of 0.71 Å (166 residues) and 1.06 Å (161 residues) for 2FAV and 5HOL, 182 respectively. Additionally, the ADP-ribose binding mode in the SARS-CoV and SARSbinds to adenine, are localized in a similar region although there are 185 slight differences in the rotamers about the Cβ-Cγ bond. The angles between the mean planes 186 defined by the OD1, CG and OD2 atoms relative to SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 is 23.1 o and 46.5 o for 187 the SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV Mac1 structures, respectively. Another notable difference is 188 that SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 macrodomains have an isoleucine (I23) following this 189 aspartic acid while MERS-CoV has an alanine (A22). Conversely, SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-190 CoV Mac1 have a valine instead of an isoleucine immediately following the GGG motif 191 (V49/I48). From these structures it appears that having two isoleucines in this location would 192 clash, and that lineage B and lineage C β -CoVs has evolved in unique ways to create space in 193 this pocket (Fig. 4D and data not shown). Despite these small differences in local structure, the 194 overall structure of CoV Mac1 domains remain remarkably conserved, and indicates they likely 195 have similar biochemical activities and biological functions. 196 SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2, and MERS-CoV bind to ADP-ribose with similar 197 affinities. To determine if the CoV macrodomains had any noticeable differences in their ability 198 to bind ADP-ribose, we performed isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), which measures the 199 energy released or absorbed during a binding reaction. Macrodomain proteins from human 200 (Mdo2), SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, and SARS-CoV-2 were purified (Fig. S1A) and tested for 201

FIGREF2.text: . MAR was rapidly removed from MARylated PARP10 with the CoV Mac1 proteins (Fig. 238 6D). Approximately 95% of MAR was removed by SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 within 239 15 minutes, while at the same timepoint MERS-CoV Mac1 removed about 85% of MAR (Fig. 240 6D). A more gradual decrease of MARylated PAPR10 band intensity was observed with Mdo2. 241 It removed approximately 70% of MAR in 30 minutes, which was significantly different from 242 both SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 Mac1. These data showed that CoV Mac1 proteins have 243 similar ADP-ribosylhydrolase activity against an auto-modified PARP10 protein and have 244 increased activity when compared to the human Mdo2 protein for this substrate under these 245conditions. However, further enzymatic analyses of these proteins are warranted to more 246 thoroughly understand their kinetics and affinities for ADP-ribosylated substrates.

The 324 cell lysate was incubated with 10 ml of Glutathione Sepharose 4B resin from GE Healthcare, 325 equilibrated with the same buffer for 2 hours, then applied to a gravity flow column to allow 326 unbound proteins to flow through. The column was washed with the resuspension buffer till the 327 absorbance at 280 nm reached baseline. The bound protein was eluted out of the column with 328 resuspension buffer containing 20mM reduced glutathione and then dialyzed back into the 329 resuspension buffer overnight at 4°C.330 Isothermal Titration Calorimetry 331 All ITC titrations were performed on a MicroCal PEAQ-ITC instrument (Malvern 332 Pananalytical Inc., MA). All reactions were performed in 20 mM Tris pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl 333 using 100 uM of all macrodomain proteins at 25°C. Titration of 2 mM ADP-ribose or ATP 334 (MilliporeSigma) contained in the stirring syringe included a single 0assay with DSF involved use of LightCycler® 480 Instrument (Roche 340 Diagnostics). In total, a 15μl mixture containing 8X SYPRO Orange (Invitrogen), and 10 uM 341 Mac1 protein in buffer containing 20 mM Hepes, NaOH, pH 7.5 and various concentrations of 342 ADP-ribose were mixed on ice in 384-well PCR plate (Roche). Fluorescent signals were 343 measured from 25 to 95 °C in 0.2 °C/30-s steps (excitation, 470-505 nm; detection, 540-700 344 nm). The main measurements were carried out in triplicate. For direct protein detection, the SDS-PAGE was 362 stained using InstantBlue® Protein Stain (Expedeon). For immunoblotting, the separated 363 proteins were transferred onto polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane using iBlot™ 2 Dry 364 Blotting System (ThermoFisher Scientific). The blot was blocked with 5% skim milk in PBS 365 containing 0.05% Tween-20 and probed with anti-mono or poly ADP-ribose binding antibodies 366 MABE1076 (α-MAR), MABC547 (α-PAR), MABE1075 (α-MAR/PAR) (Millipore-Sigma) and 367 anti-GST tag monoclonal antibody MA4-004 (ThermoFisher Scientific). The primary antibodies 368 were detected with secondary infrared anti-rabbit and anti-mouse antibodies (LI-COR 369 Biosciences). All immunoblots were visualized using Odyssey ® CLx Imaging System (LIand Data Collection: Purified SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 in 150mM NaCl, 373 20mM Tris pH 8.0 was concentrated to 13.8 mg/mL for crystallization screening. All 374 crystallization experiments were setup using an NT8 drop-setting robot (Formulatrix Inc.) and 375 UVXPO MRC (Molecular Dimensions) sitting drop vapor diffusion plates at 18°C. 100 nL of 376 protein and 100 nL crystallization solution were dispensed and equilibrated against 50 uL of the 377 latter. The SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 complex with ADP-ribose was prepared by adding the ligand, 378 from a 100 mM stock in water, to the protein at a final concentration of 2 mM. Crystals that were 379 obtained in 1-2 days from the Salt Rx HT screen (Hampton Research) condition E10 (1.8 M 380 NaH 2 PO 4 /K 2 HPO 4 , pH 8.2). Refinement screening was conducted using the additive screen HT 381 (Hampton Research) by supplementing 10% of each additive to the Salt Rx HT E10 condition in 382 a new 96-well UVXPO crystallization plate. The crystals used for data collection were obtained 383 from Salt Rx HT E10 supplemented with 0.1 M NDSB-256 from the additive screen (Fig. S1). 384 Samples were transferred to a fresh drop composed of 80% crystallization solution and 20% 385 (v/v) PEG 200 and stored in liquid nitrogen. X-ray diffraction data were collected at the 386 Advanced Photon Source, IMCA-CAT beamline 17-ID using a Dectris Eiger 2X 9M pixel array 387 detector. 388 Structure Solution and Refinement: Intensities were integrated using XDS 35,36 via 389 Autoproc 37 and the Laue class analysis and data scaling were performed with Aimless 38 . 390 Notably, a pseudo-translational symmetry peak was observed at (0, 0.31 0.5) that was 44.6% of 391 the origin. Structure solution was conducted by molecular replacement with Phaser 39 using a 392 previously determined structure of ADP-ribose bound SARS-CoV-2 Mac1 (PDB 6W02) as the 393 search model. The top solution was obtained in the space group P2 1 with four molecules in the 394 asymmetric unit. Structure refinement and manual model building were conducted with Phenix 40 395 and Coot 41 respectively. Disordered side chains were truncated to the point for which electron 396 density could be observed. Structure validation was conducted with Molprobity 42 and figures 397 were prepared using the CCP4MG package 43 . Superposition of the macrodomain structures was 398 conducted with GESAMT 44 . 399

TABREF0.text: . From these reports it is clear that CoV Mac1 is vital for the ability of 274 these viruses to cause disease, and have indicated that it could be a novel therapeutic target. 275 Despite this, there are no known compounds that inhibit this domain. The outbreak of COVID-19 276 has illustrated an incredible need for developing multiple therapeutic drugs targeting conserved 277 coronavirus proteins. Mac1 appears to be an ideal candidate for further drug development based 278 on its: i) highly conserved structure and biochemical activities within CoVs; and ii) its clear 279 importance for multiple CoVs to cause disease. Targeting Mac1 may also have the benefit of 280 enhancing the innate immune response, as we have shown that Mac1 is required for some CoVs 281 to block IFN production 16,21 . Considering that Mac1 from divergent α CoVs such as 229E and 282 FIPV also have de-ADP-ribosylating activity 14,15 , it is also possible that compounds targeting 283 Mac1 could prevent disease caused by of wide variety of CoV, including those of veterinary 284 importance like porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV). Further, compounds that inhibit Mac1 285 could help identify its protein targets during infection. Future studies could utilize the SARS-286
